body:
### Problem

When running a program directly in the terminal, if that program handles Ctrl+Z itself (as LazyGit does) to suspend itself, then the terminal is left in a hard-to-exit state: it's in input mode so all keystrokes are sent to the running program, but the running program is suspended so nothing is listening. Typing `fg` to unsuspend the program doesn't work like in Bash or other shells, because there isn't a shell in between the terminal and the suspended process. The only ways to get out of this state are:

1. Hit C-\ C-n (or some other key map mapped to the same thing) to get back into normal mode in the terminal.
2. Type `:q` to exit the terminal window, killing the suspended process

Alternately, one could find the process ID in the status line and run `kill -s CONT (pid)` to manually unsuspend the process by sending it SIGCONT, e.g. if the terminal URL is showing as `term://~/tmp/nvim//1792015:lazygit` then one can run `kill -s CONT 1792015` to unsuspend the LazyGit process and get back to normal operation.

It would be nice if the terminal could implement the same job-control mechanisms that Bash and other shells do, detecting when a child process has received SIGSTOP (which also sends SIGCHLD to the parent process, e.g. NeoVim) and allowing the `fg` command (which a Linux poweruser will likely have as a finger macro) to send SIGCONT to the child process. Or perhaps some other way of handling the situation that I haven't thought of.

This problem will probably arise only rarely, as most software apparently either doesn't catch Ctrl+Z (letting the shell catch it and send SIGSTOP to the child), or else the software handles input itself and uses Ctrl+Z for other things such as undo. So far LazyGit is the only software I've found that handles Ctrl+Z by sending itself SIGSTOP, and the terminal window isn't set up to handle that situation gracefully.

### Steps to reproduce

Run `nvim --clean`
`:term lazygit` and press Enter
Type `a` or `i` to send input to the terminal
Inside LazyGit, press C-z (Ctrl+Z) to suspend it
LazyGit sends itself SIGSTOP and suspends itself
Back at terminal in input mode, but nothing is listening to input
Look at process ID of lazygit
In another terminal (outside of NeoVim), run `ps -s CONT (pid)`
Inside NeoVim, the LazyGit process has resumed in the terminal

### Expected behavior

The terminal would notice SIGCHLD and handle it appropriately, perhaps by handling someone typing `fg<CR>` and turning that into a SIGCONT, or else by displaying a message like `[Process suspended, press any key to resume it]`.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

v0.11.5, and also v0.12.0-dev-2103+g95b03171df

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

Yes, vim 9.1.2077

### Operating system/version

Arch Linux

### Terminal name/version

ghostty 1.2.3-arch2

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-ghostty

### Installation

Arch package manager (pacman -S neovim)
title: Terminal doesn't detect when a process inside it has suspended itself with Ctrl+Z, not easy to resume
